bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Florence M. Read, December 9, 1926

div1.p: Carter describes her progress on Henry Rose Carter's History of Yellow Fever and asks about reimbursement for expenses she has incurred in her research.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Florence M. Read, December 9, 1926
div1.opener:
Book
Morley (conferences)
------------
The Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene
and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
December 9, 1926.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
I am enclosing herewith a brief Memorandum of two conferences
I have had within the past few weeks, with Dr. Sylvanus Griswold Morley
of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, in regard to that part of
of the History of Yellow Fever embraced in Section 111: Part 1 and Part
1 Continued.

I am very enthusiastic about what has been accomplished, both
in regard to the material selected and in the promptitude with which
Dr. Morley has gotten the actual work of its preparation for the book
under way. I think we now have just what we need pictorially to round
out this section from a geographic and archaeological standpoint.

By the way, I have mislaid the expense account book that Dr.
Russell gave me in October 1925. May I have another? My expenses
heretofore, in connection with the Hisottory of Yellow Fever (typewriting
supplies: note books etc. etc.) have been so small that I really did
not feel justified in sending them in: while the tracings from the three
Nahuatl Codices (mentioned in the enclosed Mem.) I paid for myself, be-
cause you have all been so beautifully kind when I have had to “slow up”
“slow up”
-2-
on the book (notably from the ptomaine poisoning of last spring).

Now, however, I've had to make the two trips to Washington (one
involving a stay of two days) and there will be other expenses (retyping
MSS: map outlines etc) in the comparatively near future.

In this connection, how do I handle things of this kind? Pay
the bills myself and send in the receipts with my expense book?

I know you will be glad to hear that I was able to turn over,
to Dr. Frost, the rough copy of the revised MSS of Section 1 (Epidemio-
logy) a couple of weeks ago. It was the hardest piece of work connected
with the book (transcribing a mass Father's final notes (almost microscopic in
the chirography and also in a sort of code of his own, which no one but he
and myself could read: Indeed, he didn't intend them to be read--just
jotted them down to dictate to me later). Frost considers them very
valuable, however--adding much to the interest of the book, The MSS
has been cut, where[unclear]ver they were to be inserted and they have been pasted
in--rather than pinned--so as to avoid any mistake in retyping. Dr.
Russell has wisely suggested that this retyping should be done twice and
I shall shall have the first copy started as soon as Dr. Frost returns
the MSS. of this Section.

In the meantime, there is an abundance to be done on the rest of
the book, so that there is no delay involved in any case.
div1.closer:
With very best remembrances to you all,
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter 1 enclosure.
Miss Florence M. Read, Executive Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
